Electric-Field.title: Electric Charges and Fields
Electric-Field.summary: This chapter introduces the fundamental concepts of electric charges, Coulomb's law, electric fields, and Gauss's law. It explains how charges interact, the nature of electric fields, and how to calculate them for different charge distributions. Key topics include conservation and quantization of charge, superposition principle, electric dipoles, and electric field lines.
formulas: Coulomb's Law: F = (1 / 4πε₀) × (q₁q₂ / r²)
Electric Field (E) due to a point charge: E = (1 / 4πε₀) × (q / r²)
Force on a charge in an electric field: F = qE
Electric Dipole Moment: p = q × 2a
Torque on a dipole in an electric field: τ = p × E (or τ = pE sinθ)
Electric Field due to an infinite plane sheet: E = σ / (2ε₀)
Electric Field due to a uniformly charged infinite line: E = λ / (2πε₀r)
Gauss's Law: ∮E · dA = Q_enclosed / ε₀
derivations: Electric field due to a point charge (from Coulomb's Law)
Electric field due to an electric dipole (axial and equatorial positions)
Torque on an electric dipole in a uniform electric field
Electric field due to an infinite line of charge (using Gauss's Law)
Electric field due to a uniformly charged spherical shell (inside and outside using Gauss's Law)

Electrostatic-Potential.title: Electrostatic Potential and Capacitance
Electrostatic-Potential.summary: This chapter builds on the concept of electric fields by introducing electric potential, potential energy, and equipotential surfaces. It then moves to capacitors, their capacitance, combinations, and the energy stored in them. The behavior of dielectrics in electric fields is also discussed.
formulas: Electric Potential (V) due to a point charge: V = (1 / 4πε₀) × (q / r)
Electric Potential Difference: ΔV = W / q₀
Electric Potential Energy (U) of a system of two charges: U = (1 / 4πε₀) × (q₁q₂ / r)
Potential Energy of an electric dipole in an electric field: U = -p · E = -pE cosθ
Capacitance (C): C = Q / V
Capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor: C = ε₀A / d
Capacitance with dielectric: C = K C₀
Capacitors in Series: 1/C_eq = 1/C₁ + 1/C₂ + ...
Capacitors in Parallel: C_eq = C₁ + C₂ + ...
Energy stored in a capacitor: U = ½CV² = ½Q²/C = ½QV
Energy density of electric field: u = ½ε₀E²
derivations: Electric potential due to a point charge
Electric potential due to an electric dipole
Potential energy of a system of charges
Capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor (with and without dielectric)
Equivalent capacitance for series and parallel combinations
Energy stored in a capacitor

Current-Electricity.title: Current Electricity
Current-Electricity.summary: This chapter deals with electric current, Ohm's law, resistance, and the factors affecting it. It covers series and parallel combinations of resistors, Kirchhoff's laws for complex circuits, and the Wheatstone bridge. Concepts like internal resistance of a cell, electromotive force (emf), and power dissipation are also explained.
formulas: Electric Current (I): I = Q / t (or I = n e A v_d)
Ohm's Law: V = IR
Resistance (R): R = ρ(L/A)
Resistors in Series: R_eq = R₁ + R₂ + ...
Resistors in Parallel: 1/R_eq = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + ...
Power (P): P = VI = I²R = V²/R
Internal Resistance of a cell: V = E - Ir
Kirchhoff's Junction Rule (Current Law): ΣI = 0 (at a junction)
Kirchhoff's Loop Rule (Voltage Law): ΣΔV = 0 (around a closed loop)
Wheatstone Bridge balance condition: P/Q = R/S
Meter Bridge formula: R/S = l₁ / (100 - l₁)
derivations: Drift velocity and its relation with current
Ohm's law (microscopic form and macroscopic form)
Equivalent resistance for series and parallel combinations
Kirchhoff's laws (conceptual applications)
Wheatstone bridge balance condition

Moving-Charges-Magnetism.title: Moving Charges and Magnetism
Moving-Charges-Magnetism.summary: This chapter introduces the magnetic effects of electric current. It covers the Biot-Savart Law and Ampere's Circuital Law for calculating magnetic fields due to various current configurations. The force on moving charges and current-carrying conductors in magnetic fields, torque on a current loop, and working of moving coil galvanometer are also explained.
formulas: Lorentz Force: F = q(E + v × B)
Force on a moving charge in a magnetic field: F = q(v × B) = qvB sinθ
Force on a current-carrying conductor: F = I(L × B) = BIL sinθ
Magnetic Field (B) due to a straight current-carrying conductor (Ampere's Law): B = μ₀I / (2πr)
Magnetic Field at the center of a circular loop: B = μ₀I / (2R)
Magnetic Field on the axis of a circular loop: B = (μ₀IR² / 2(R² + x²)^(3/2))
Magnetic Field inside a long solenoid: B = μ₀nI
Torque on a current loop in a uniform magnetic field: τ = M × B = NIAB sinθ
Magnetic Dipole Moment of a current loop: M = IA
Force between two parallel current-carrying conductors: F/L = μ₀I₁I₂ / (2πd)
derivations: Biot-Savart Law (conceptual understanding and applications)
Ampere's Circuital Law (conceptual understanding and applications)
Magnetic field due to a straight current-carrying wire (using Ampere's Law)
Magnetic field inside a solenoid (using Ampere's Law)
Force between two parallel current-carrying conductors
Torque on a current loop in a uniform magnetic field

Magnetism-Matter.title: Magnetism and Matter
Magnetism-Matter.summary: This chapter explores the fundamental properties of magnets and magnetic materials. It discusses the Earth's magnetism, magnetic field lines, and the behavior of various magnetic materials (diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic) in external magnetic fields. Concepts like magnetic dipole moment, magnetic intensity, and magnetic susceptibility are introduced.
formulas: Magnetic field due to a magnetic dipole (Bar Magnet) on axial line: B = (μ₀ / 4π) × (2M / r³)
Magnetic field due to a magnetic dipole (Bar Magnet) on equatorial line: B = (μ₀ / 4π) × (M / r³)
Torque on a magnetic dipole in a magnetic field: τ = M × B = MB sinθ
Potential Energy of a magnetic dipole in a magnetic field: U = -M · B = -MB cosθ
Relation between B, H, and M: B = μ₀(H + M)
Magnetic Susceptibility: χ_m = M / H
Relative Permeability: μ_r = 1 + χ_m
derivations: Magnetic field due to a bar magnet (as an equivalent solenoid)
Torque and potential energy of a magnetic dipole in a magnetic field
Relationship between B, H, and M (conceptual)

Electromagnetic-Induction.title: Electromagnetic Induction
Electromagnetic-Induction.summary: This chapter deals with the phenomenon of electromagnetic induction, where a changing magnetic flux induces an electromotive force (emf) and current. It covers Faraday's laws of induction, Lenz's law, motional emf, eddy currents, and self-induction and mutual induction. The concept of AC generator is also introduced.
formulas: Magnetic Flux (Φ_B): Φ_B = B · A = BA cosθ
Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction: ε = -N (dΦ_B / dt)
Motional EMF: ε = Blv sinθ (for a conductor moving in a uniform field)
Self-Inductance (L): L = Φ_B / I
EMF induced in an inductor: ε = -L (dI / dt)
Energy stored in an inductor: U = ½LI²
Mutual Inductance (M): M = Φ_B₂ / I₁
EMF induced due to mutual induction: ε₂ = -M (dI₁ / dt)
derivations: Faraday's laws of electromagnetic induction
Lenz's law (conceptual, conservation of energy)
Motional EMF (from Lorentz force and from change in flux)
Energy stored in an inductor
Self-inductance and mutual inductance

Alternating-Current.title: Alternating Current
Alternating-Current.summary: This chapter explores the characteristics and behavior of alternating current (AC). It covers AC voltage and current, phase difference, reactance (inductive and capacitive), impedance, and series LCR circuits. Concepts like resonance, quality factor, AC generator, and transformer are also discussed.
formulas: Instantaneous AC voltage: V = V₀ sin(ωt)
Instantaneous AC current: I = I₀ sin(ωt + φ)
RMS values: V_rms = V₀ / √2, I_rms = I₀ / √2
Inductive Reactance (X_L): X_L = ωL = 2πfL
Capacitive Reactance (X_C): X_C = 1 / (ωC) = 1 / (2πfC)
Impedance (Z) for LCR series circuit: Z = √(R² + (X_L - X_C)²)
Phase angle (φ): tanφ = (X_L - X_C) / R
Resonant Frequency (f_r or ω_r): f_r = 1 / (2π√(LC)) or ω_r = 1 / √(LC)
Average Power in AC circuit: P_avg = V_rms I_rms cosφ (where cosφ is power factor)
Transformer relation: V_s / V_p = N_s / N_p = I_p / I_s
Quality factor (Q): Q = ω_rL / R = 1 / (ω_rCR)
derivations: RMS values of AC voltage and current
Inductive and capacitive reactance
Impedance of an LCR series circuit (phasor diagram method)
Resonant frequency for an LCR series circuit
Average power in an AC circuit (power factor)
Transformer equations

Electromagnetic-Waves.title: Electromagnetic Waves
Electromagnetic-Waves.summary: This chapter introduces the concept of electromagnetic waves, their properties, and the electromagnetic spectrum. It discusses the displacement current introduced by Maxwell and the four Maxwell's equations. The transverse nature of EM waves, their speed in vacuum and media, and their energy and momentum are also covered.
formulas: Speed of EM waves in vacuum: c = 1 / √(μ₀ε₀)
Speed of EM waves in medium: v = 1 / √(με)
Relation between E and B field amplitudes: c = E₀ / B₀
Energy density of electric field: u_E = ½ε₀E²
Energy density of magnetic field: u_B = ½B² / μ₀
Poynting Vector (S): S = (1/μ₀)(E × B)
Displacement Current (I_d): I_d = ε₀ (dΦ_E / dt)
Maxwell's Equations (conceptual understanding):
1. Gauss's Law for Electrostatics: ∮E · dA = Q_enclosed / ε₀
2. Gauss's Law for Magnetism: ∮B · dA = 0
3. Faraday's Law: ∮E · dl = -dΦ_B / dt
4. Ampere-Maxwell Law: ∮B · dl = μ₀(I_c + I_d) = μ₀(I_c + ε₀ dΦ_E / dt)
derivations: Maxwell's modification of Ampere's Circuital Law (displacement current)
Derivation of the speed of electromagnetic waves from Maxwell's equations (conceptual)
Transverse nature of EM waves (qualitative)
